TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Do you claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do.
—Please proceed.
—On 29 November Senator Crichton-Browne stated in the Senate in relation to me:

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps he should have applied for New South Wales police where he would have fitted in very well.

Whatever Senator Crichton-Browne meant by this is unclear. However, if in any way he was attempting to impugn my reputation as a former police officer, he ought to be mindful that one of my referees during the recent preselection to the seat of Moore was the current Deputy Commissioner of the WA Police. He actually did agree to be a referee in my case, which is in stark contrast to Senator Crichton-Browne where his so-called referees made public statements that they had not been asked to be his referees and if asked would have refused. I might point out that the Deputy Commissioner was appointed by the Court government cabinet.

PARA.TAB: Senator Crichton-Browne went on to say in relation to me `he scrutineered the results of one of his own branches' as if there were something wrong with that. The election was for branch officers and delegates for the Joondalup branch. I was appointed by the meeting along with Paul Stevenage, a preselection rival. The chairman of the meeting was none other than David Honey, the state president and former ally of Senator Crichton-Browne. Senator Crichton-Browne's accusation that somehow being a scrutineer—

TALK.START.PARA: —I do take the nod and the wink I am getting from some in this place this morning that perhaps we are getting into debate on an issue. If you show where you have been misrepresented, that is fine. There is an adjournment this afternoon. Would you like to kick on then?
—Can I have a guarantee, again? In the second part of the paragraph he stated:

SPEECH.PARA: He was provided with the results by the returning officer and asked to pass them on to the divisional secretary. But in the process, he had them typed up in his own office and changed the result to one which materially benefited him and benefited his prospects of preselection.

That is untrue, as he well knows, and has been established by his former party's own state executive. Ironically, the matter revolved around a complaint that three people who stood for office and participated in an annual general meeting in another branch on 16 August 1994 suddenly appeared as participants in the other branch on 22 August.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Moore has had a reasonable go I think.
—Could I just finish the last two things?
—If you believe you have been misrepresented twice more, keep it brief.

—In the last part of the speech he claims that Ian Viner presented a statutory declaration in 1989 to the effect that I had attempted to bribe a delegate to the 1989 preselection when I beat former mayor Wayne Bradshaw. The person who made the statutory declaration was Julie Debnam, a close friend of Wayde Smith and Wayne Bradshaw, who was most recently seen on television tearfully hugging Senator Crichton-Browne outside the state executive meeting when they decided to expel him from the party. Ian Viner did not present this declaration. Wayne Bradshaw did—
—This is fascinating in Western Australia, as I am sure it is in other parts of Australia, but I think the honourable member has been given a fair enough go to show where he has been misrepresented.
