TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 18 September 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Does the Government support the co-location, where possible, of telecommunications infrastructure.
(2) Who owns the conduits carrying Telstra's telecommunications cabling.
(3) Do most of Telstra's telephone cables run underground in 50 millimetre conduits.
(4) Does Optus propose to carry pay TV and other telecommunications services mostly on 17 millimetre cable.
(5) Is there any technical reason why Optus and Telstra cables could not both fit into existing underground telecommunications conduits.
(6) Does the Government prefer that Optus place its cables (a) overhead via power poles or (b) underground.
(7) Would laying new underground conduits of its own place Optus at an additional competitive disadvantage against Telstra.

(8) Would placing cables on power poles (a) generate significant community opposition, (b) result in consequent local government objections under the Telecommunications National Code and (c) further delay the establishment of Optus' own network.
(9) Will the Government ensure fair competition by instructing Telstra to make space inside its existing underground conduits available to Optus.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Government has in place measures to encourage the co-location of telecommunications infrastructure.

Under the Telecommunications National Code, carriers are required to co-locate new facilities (towers or similar structures) on towers unless it is not technically feasible; is incompatible with the network configuration; or is likely to have a greater adverse effect on the environment than putting a new facility in another place.

In addition, under the Telecommunications National Code, carriers are required, among other things, to take all reasonable steps to use existing sites and facilities used by public utilities to supply products or services.

The Telecommunications (General Telecommunications Licences) Declaration (No. 1) of 1991, made under the Telecommunications Act 1991, requires carriers to provide other carriers with access to specified infrastructure including ducts that were in place on 30 June 1991, if it is reasonable to do so. Carriers are also required to provide access to this infrastructure where it was acquired on any basis other than full commercial negotiation, if it is reasonable to do so. This access is on terms and conditions, as agreed from time to time by the carriers, or failing agreement, as determined by AUSTEL under the Telecommunications (Interconnection and Related Charging Principles) Determination No 1 of 1991.
(2) I am advised that Telstra owns the conduits carrying Telstra's telecommunications cabling.

(3) I am advised by Telstra that the size of conduits varies. Older suburbs can have conduits as narrow as 20 millimetres. Generally suburban conduit is around 50 millimetres in diameter. Wider streets tend to have wider conduit because they carry the bulk of cables, while side streets require only smaller branch-like conduits of 50 millimetres. In newer estates conduit tends to be 80 to 100 millimetres.
(4) I am advised by Optus that the full range of services offered by Optus—local telephony, pay television and interactive services—will be mostly offered through a single 17 millimetre cable.

(5) As indicated in answer to question (1), carriers are required to allow access to their conduits where reasonable. I am advised by Telstra that Optus has approximately 1000 kilometres of its telephony cable in Telstra's underground network. Shared underground placement of telephony cable had been mostly in trunk routes where large pipes for inter-exchange links or CBD loops lead to space being available.
I am advised that there are reasons why it may not be feasible for carriers to share conduits.

Firstly, there is often not enough room in existing conduit to introduce new cabling. I am advised that, for example, in undertaking its major upgrade of underground conduit, Telstra will have to expand approximately 50 per cent of conduit ducting. Secondly, space may need to be retained to enable effective maintenance. Thirdly, insertion of new cable in conduits where there is insufficient space may damage existing cable. Carriers may also wish to retain spare space for growth in their own network.

(6) The decision whether cable is installed overhead via power poles or underground is a commercial one for the carriers, subject to the carriers' deployment abiding by relevant Commonwealth legislation (including in particular Part 7 of the Telecommunications Act 1991 and the Telecommunications National Code).

(7) The Government in establishing its telecommunications regime in 1991 put in place a regime which would enable carriers to compete with each other on an equal basis in providing telecommunications networks and services. This regime included basic rights of interconnection between carriers and rights of access. This enables carriers to interconnect with each other's networks and to share infrastructure when provision of additional infrastructure is considered commercially undesirable. Within this environment, it is a commercial decision for carriers how they deploy their networks.

(8)(a) I am advised by Optus that it has undertaken a significant community information program in the areas in which it deploys its cable network. The program involves individual contact with each household. Optus has advised that research indicates that opposition decreases once the community becomes aware of the full benefits of the network, including an alternative competitive local telephone services and access to the superhighway of the future.

(b) Carriers when rolling out cable for their network are required to comply with the Telecommunications National Code. The Code establishes procedures whereby environmental, heritage and development issues can be adequately considered. The Code requires that carriers notify relevant authorities including local government, and provide them with details, of the carriers' proposed cabling rollout activities (underground or overhead).

(c) Such consultations with Local Government organisations are provided for under the Telecommunications National Code to enable consultation with local communities. The degree to which local government expresses concerns and the time taken to address these concerns may vary. However, to ensure that there cannot be indefinite delays to the carriers' network roll-out the Code provides for an upper limit on the period of consultation.
(9) See answers to questions (1) and (5).

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 25 September 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a matter described in Public Interest Advocacy Centre Bulletin No. 5 for May/June 1995 in which the Public Interest Advocacy Centre Clearing House was unable to obtain legal advice for a resident group concerned about the health implications of a telecommunications development because a number of legal firms had undertaken not to act against it.
(2) Has the matter referred to in part (1) been examined; if so, (a) what steps have been taken in response and (b) what findings have been made on the behaviour of the legal firms.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes.

(2) The matter raises issues under the Trade Practices Act 1974 which have been considered by the Trade Practices Commission. The successor of the Trade Practices Commission, the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (the ACCC), has advised that the conduct in question could fall for consideration under section 47 of the Trade Practices Act. Section 47 prohibits a corporation from engaging in exclusive dealing but only if the conduct has the purpose or effect of substantially lessening competition in the relevant market. The ACCC has formed the view that, given the large number of legal firms whose services are available in the Sydney region, it would seem unlikely that an exclusive dealing arrangement involving 43 firms would substantially lessen competition and, therefore, the conduct in question would be unlikely to contravene the Act. In this regard, I note that, while the matter to which you have referred made it difficult for the resident group to obtain legal assistance to challenge an action of the telecommunications corporation, it appears that legal assistance eventually became available to the group.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 18 October 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has his or the Australian Securities Commission's (ASC) attention been drawn to the 1995 annual report of the Hills Motorway Group, in particular to:
(a) the non-recognition in The Hills Motorway Limited's (THM Limited) profit and loss account of the payment of $8.99 million from THM Limited to Hills Motorway Trust (the Trust);

(b) the capitalisation of actual cash paid for interest payments ($8.99 million), directors' fees ($149 000), indemnification and insurance of directors (not specified), preliminary expenses ($122 000) and administration expenses ($470 000);
(c) the listing in the balance sheet, as asset items, of prepayment of interest of $37.51 million comprising current $15.5 million and noncurrent $22.01 million;
(d) the appearance that non-current liabilities have not been provided for;
(e) the statement in note 2 of the accounts that interest of $47.718 million has been paid; and
(f) the conclusion in the accounts that THM Limited is worth $1.55 million.

(2) Is the ASC satisfied of the appropriateness of treating the sum of $37.51 million referred to in part (1)(c) as an asset item when (a) it represents obligations or future liabilities on the infrastructure loan to THM Limited from the trust and (b) balancing non-current liabilities referred to in part (1)(d) have not been provided for.
(3) Has the ASC satisfied itself that THM Limited does not have negative net worth.
(4) Is it a fact that expense items of THM Limited have been or are being paid for by the Trust settled through an inter-company account or otherwise.
(5) Has the ASC investigated or will it investigate whether expense items of THM Limited have appropriately been paid for by (a) the Trust or (b) Perpetual Trustees Australia Limited.

(6) Further to the answer to part (4)(b) of the question No. 2394 (Hansard, 30 August 1995, page 920), what are the results of the ASC's monitoring or investigation of Sydney's M2 motorway project and the companies and other entities associated with it.
(7) Has his or the ASC's attention been drawn to:
(a) the non-recognition in the Trust's profit and loss account of $8.99 million received from THM Limited and not recognised in THM Limited's accounts;

(b) the Trust's loan to THM Limited being shown as $169.463 million, without provision for diminution in the value of the loan to reflect the potential and apparent inconsistencies or discontinuities in THM Limited's accounts;
(c) the sum of $42.519 million being shown for property, plant and equipment without allowance for amortisation or depreciation; and

(d) the inclusion of borrowing costs and preliminary expenses of $26.05 million and apparent non-deduction of $9 million of distribution to shareholders from the sum of $153.407 million shown as unit holders' equity and the consequent appearance that the value of each unit trust as being 99 cents is overstated.

(8) Has the matter of compliance with the requirements of the Trust's deed of trust, in particular the requirement that borrowings not exceed 80 per cent of the gross assets, been drawn to the ASC's attention and investigated; if so, what (a) are the details of the matter and (b) was the result of the investigation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answers to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) I am advised by the ASC that it is aware of the 1995 annual report of the Hills Motorway Group. The ASC has provided the following comments concerning the items mentioned in the honourable member's question:

(a) The interest expenses of $8.99 million from THM Limited to the Trust had been capitalised and shown under leasehold improvement at notes 9 and l(e). Therefore they were not shown in the profit and loss account of THM Limited. Capitalised expenditure is to be amortised when the motorway becomes operational. This accounting treatment is considered to be proper.

(b) Provided that all these expenses can be directly related to the project and that they are not overvalued, it is appropriate to capitalise them. Capitalised expenses will have to be amortised once the motorway starts receiving income.
(c) Prepaid interest should properly be shown as an asset on the balance sheet.

(d) In the abridged aggregated financial statements of the group set out in the annual report, the non-current liability due by THM Limited to the Trust had been eliminated in order to show the position of the Group. This is intended to reflect the substance of the transaction from the investors' point of view. The abridged aggregated accounts are for the unit holders/shareholders' information only and have no standing under the Corporations Law.

(e) The cash flow statement shows that the amount in question has been paid by THM Limited. Among the $47.7 million, $8.99 million was shown as revenue in the profit and loss account of the Trust and the balance was shown as unearned income on the Trust's balance sheet.

(f) Based on information provided in the financial statements, this is the net worth of the company. The ASC is not aware of any improper accounting treatments which would affect the net worth of the company.

(2) I am advised by the ASC that the accounting treatment of the sum $37.5 million as an asset item is independent of the liabilities of the company. Prepayments are an asset. The non-current liabilities referred to are not brought to account in the abridged aggregated financial statements as explained in answer to l(d).

(3) I am advised by the ASC that, in the absence of any further information, it would rely on the accounts provided by the directors and audited by Ernst & Young, which do not indicate negative net worth. The ASC further advises that, at this stage, it has not received any information which causes it to require further substantiation.
(4) I am advised by the ASC that information to the effect suggested was provided in the accounts of THM Limited and the Trust as related party disclosures.

(5) I am advised by the ASC that, in relation to the M2 Motorway project generally, THM Limited is responsible for supervising the design, construction, operation and maintenance of the M2 Motorway, while the Trustee is the sole borrower for the project and finances the project. The Trust receives rent from THM Limited in the form of sub-lease payments and makes interest and principal payments on the project debt, pays Trust expenses and makes distributions to investors. Under the terms of the Project Funding Deed entered into by the Trustee, THM Limited and Hills Motorway Construction Company Pty Limited (a wholly owned subsidiary of THM Limited), all monies received by the Trust and by THM Limited are required to be deposited in accounts established in compliance with the Deed. The Agent, Westpac Banking Corporation, is then required to make certain withdrawals and transfers between the accounts. The rights of all other parties to operate the accounts are restricted.
Any payments made by Perpetual Trustee Limited would have been made as trustee of the Trust. Such payments would be made only on the basis of a recommendation by the Manager of the Trust.

In view of the structure in place for this project, the transfer of monies between the Trust and THM Limited would be expected. Based on the information currently available, the ASC has advised that it has no reason to believe that any expenses have been improperly paid or have not been paid in accordance with the various agreements, including the Project Funding Deed and the Trust Deed establishing the Trust. It would appear that no inappropriate payments have been identified by either the auditor or the Trustee of the Trust. Accordingly, in the absence of any suspected contravention of the Corporations Law, the ASC would not propose to investigate the matter at this time.

(6) I am advised by the ASC that nothing has come to its attention which would suggest that either the prospectus for the M2 motorway project contained any material breach of the Corporations Law or that any of the companies associated with the project have committed any breach of the Corporations Law with respect to the project.
(7) The ASC has provided the following comments concerning the items mentioned in the honourable member's question:
(a) The amount of $8.99 million was shown at page 42 of the Trust account. The amount has been recognised in THM Limited's accounts as explained at 1(a).
(b) Unless there is information that the loan will be wholly or partly uncollectible, there is no reason for provision for diminution in value to be made.

(c) The full amount for property, plant and equipment was related to leasehold improvement. It will not be amortised or depreciated until the motorway is finished and starts operating. It would not be proper to amortise this item until income commences when income and expenses can be matched.

(d) The ASC's attention has been drawn to the inclusion of borrowing costs and preliminary expenses of $26.05 million as an asset in the Trust, the treatment of which would appear to be appropriate. The distribution to unit holders of $9 million included $8.99 million interest income of the Trust, which does not have to be deducted from unit holders' equity. The balance of the distribution has been deducted from the unit holders' equity. The issue price of units in the trust was 99 cents, although the net asset backing for each stapled security (that is, one share in THM Limited and one unit in the Hills Motorway Trust) was estimated in the prospectus to be 83 cents. The value, on the basis of net asset backing, for units in the Trust was not shown as 99 cents. The Trust is now a listed Trust and the value of the stapled securities is determined by the market. As the market trades the stapled securities and not units in the Trust and shares in THM Limited separately, the market does not ascribe a separate value for the units in the Trust and the shares. Each set of financial statements will provide information regarding the net asset backing for units in the Trust and shares in the company.

(8) I am advised by the ASC that it is apparent from the audited trust accounts that the borrowings at 30 June 1995 did not exceed 80% of the gross assets. The ASC is not aware of any instances where the borrowing limit has been exceeded. In accordance with the Trust Deed, should that limit be exceeded, the Manager of the Trust is obliged to notify the Trustee that this has occurred and take appropriate steps to remedy the default as soon as possible. On the basis of the information before it, the ASC has no reason to believe that either the Manager or the Trustee has failed to comply with its obligations under the Trust Deed.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 18 October 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the projections in the NRMA's prospectus of 23 August 1994 of:
(a) a total profit before tax for 1994-95 of $262 million;
(b) a consolidated profit after tax and before amortisation of goodwill for 1994-95 of $215 million;
(c) earnings per share for 1994-95 of 19.7 cents;
(d) an interim dividend of 6 cents per share payable in April 1995 and a final dividend of 7 cents per share payable in October 1995;
(e) dividends being fully franked at 39 per cent on the assumption that the reduction of capital outlined in the prospectus would proceed;
(f) a total dividend of 13 cents per share for 1995-96 equivalent to a yield of 6.5 per cent based on a share price of $2; and
(g) the dividends representing a payout of 66 per cent of after tax profits.
(2) Has his attention been drawn to claims that the projections referred to in part (1) were incorrect at the time they were made.
(3) Has it been established that:
(a) reports and updates of the NRMA's profit trends and financial position are received by NRMA (i) management fortnightly and (ii) directors monthly;
(b) the period ending 31 March 1994 was the basis of the consolidated balance sheet shown at page 57 of the prospectus;
(c) the pro forma accounts as at 30 June 1994 were the basis for the calculation of the share value of the estimated free shares referred to at pages 28 and 57 of the prospectus;
(d) the period ended 31 March 1994 was a period of highly inflated profits unsuitable as a basis for forecasting profits;

(e) Mr Ray Willing, the Chief Executive Officer of NRMA Limited and the Managing Director of NRMA Insurers Limited, publicly admitted before he resigned that it was entirely unrealistic to expect the NRMA to make profits in 1994-1995 based on its performance to 30 June 1994;

(f) between April, May and June 1994, significant losses were sustained in NRMA Insurance Limited's investment portfolio associated with a sudden collapse of the bond market, the general retreat of share markets throughout the world and the deterioration in the compulsory third party insurance portfolio;

(g) the executive management and inner circle of directors knew or ought to have known (i) before 31 July 1994 or the issue of the prospectus dated 23 August 1994 and (ii) during the six-week period it was mailed to members that (A) there was no credible prospect of the forecast consolidated profit after tax and before amortisation of goodwill realising $215 million and (B) consequently the stated expected value of the share at $2 was falsely based;

(h) the executive management and inner circle of directors proceeded to publish and distribute to over 1.8 million members copies of a prospectus containing falsely based predictions of share prices and dividends;

(i) the directors failed to inform the Australian Securities Commission (ASC), the Australian Stock Exchange, NRMA members and the investing public that the expected value of the share was falsely based and that a supplementary prospectus should be issued;
(j) by 31 December 1994 the net value of the NRMA was reduced by approximately $300 million;

(k) senior management admitted in explaining the loss that the unrealised gains of the share portfolio contained in the pro forma 30 June 1994 balance sheet were a completely unrealistic basis on which to project a profit for 1994-1995;

(l) senior management, as members of the Insurance Investment Committee, would have, (i) been aware (A) on a day-by-day basis between March and May 1994 that the NRMA Insurance Investment portfolio was making large losses on the bond market and (B) by 23 August 1994 that the trend for interest rates was to rise thereby depressing the value of the NRMA's share portfolio, (ii) known that there was no prospect of the NRMA earning $215 million or the approximately $140 million required to pay the predicted 1994-1995 dividends from profits and (iii) known that dividends would have to be paid from the provision for the reduction of capital of $517 million provided in the prospectus and it was false to suggest that dividends could be paid from profits;

(m) senior management (i) published circulars from June 1994 that promised NRMA members that they would receive a minimum of $500 worth of free shares which might be worth more, (ii) repeated the promise in advertising and (iii) implied the promise in the prospectus; and
(n) the NRMA continued to make losses after the prospectus was published because of increased compulsory third party claims and severe losses in its share portfolio.

(4) Did the NRMA's annual report for 1995 (a) show for the Consolidated NRMA Group a loss of $62.685 million after applicable income tax and extraordinary items compared with a profit of $59.704 million for 1994 and a loss on outside equity interest of $63.141 million compared with a profit of $54.97 million for 1994 and (b) claim that the losses were made notwithstanding considerable successes in other activities.

(5) Is it a fact that Ms Lynn Ralph, Deputy Chairperson of the ASC and Vice-President of NRMA Limited (a) was a director of NRMA Limited during the development and promotion of the prospectus and (b) supported the NRMA float; if so, what was the impact of her dual role of the ASC's investigation of the matters referred to in the preceding parts of this question.

(6) Is it also a fact that the ASC was in court amicus curae and consistently supported the NRMA during Federal Court proceedings before Justice Gummow and the subsequent appeal to the Full Federal Court.

(7) Did Mr Alan Cameron, Chairperson of the ASC, in giving evidence to the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Corporations and Securities, (a) represent the Federal Court's finding that the prospectus was misleading and deceptive as being merely a matter of opinion as to language with respect to the prospectus' reference to free shares and (b) not refer to the Federal Court's view that the absence of a "No" case from the prospectus was a serious omission.

(8) Has his attention been drawn to (a) a brief obtained by the Boards of the NRMA from Minter Ellison Solicitors dated 2 June 1995 and (b) an advice from Mr Jeff Sher, QC, of Counsel dated 16 August which have been tendered in evidence in an action brought by Mr Richard Talbot, an NRMA director, against the directors of NRMA Holdings Limited, before Justice Burchett of the Federal Court.
(9) Will he seek to obtain copies of the documents referred to in part (9) with the permission of the Court.

(10) Is it a fact that the ASC has not offered to support Ms Dawn Fraser and Mr Richard Talbot in their Federal Court actions to protect NRMA interests and assets despite the Federal Court's ruling that the prospectus was misleading and deceptive.
(11) Will he or the ASC cause an investigation of the matters referred to in the preceding parts of this question and make the results of the investigation available to the public; if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes. I am also advised that the ASC is aware of the matters outlined in part 1 of the question.

(2) No. I am also advised that the ASC is not aware of any specific claims that the projections referred to in part 1 were incorrect at the time they were made. The ASC is aware of and has considered the fact that the results for the financial year ended 30 June 1995 for NRMA Limited and NRMA Insurance Limited were at variance with the projections for that period contained in the prospectus dated 23 August 1994.

(3)(a) It is not clear from the question who is supposed to have established these matters. However, I will answer the question on the assumption that it is asking whether the ASC has established these matters.

I am advised that the ASC is not aware of the internal reporting structures of NRMA. The ASC is aware that the Boards of NRMA Limited and NRMA Insurance Limited meet monthly and is aware that reports by management on performance are presented at those meetings.

(b) I am advised that the information on page 57 of the prospectus for NRMA dated 23 August 1994 consists of a summarised consolidated balance sheet as at 31 March 1994 based on the audited accounts at that date and a pro forma consolidated balance sheet as at 30 June 1994. The pro forma balance sheet as at 30 June 1994 was based on the audited 31 March 1994 balance sheet and then adjusted for a number of items which are summarised on page 58 of the prospectus.

(c) I am advised that the answer is yes. I am advised that the basis used for estimating the market value of the shares at approximately $2.00 per share is detailed on page 28 of the prospectus. The estimated price was calculated as if NRMA Holdings had been listed on the Australian Stock Exchange at 30 June 1994. The prospectus says:

"The total market value is calculated with reference to the multiple of reported net tangible assets (at 31 December 1993) of the companies which comprised the Insurance Index at 30 June 1994 and with reference to the forecast 1994/1995 price earnings multiples of those companies. Share prices at 30 June 1994 were used in calculating these multiples."

This indicates that the NRMA had reference to the multiple to net tangible assets and the price/earnings multiples of other insurance companies in assessing the estimated total market value of NRMA Holdings Limited and consequently the estimated market value of NRMA shares. The pro forma balance sheet for NRMA Holdings Limited was then used to provide the net tangible asset value of $1.72 per share and the basis for a market value which was estimated at a market capitalisation of 1.17 times net tangible assets, or $2.00 per share, as shown at page 28 of the prospectus.

(d) This is a question which asks for an opinion or exercise of judgement. However, I am advised that the consolidated profit after income tax for the nine months ended 31 March 1994 is shown in the table set out on page 64 of the prospectus to be consistent, on a proportional basis, with the corresponding item for the years ended 30 June 1992 and 30 June 1993. The estimated consolidated profit after income tax for the full year ended 30 June 1994, which is set out on page 52 of the prospectus, is substantially less than the consolidated profits after tax for either of the years ended 30 June 1992 or 30 June 1993.

The prospectus states: "The forecast for the NRMA for 1994/1995 is based on budgets prepared by management as part of the usual budgeting process and adopted by the directors of NRMA Holdings." The profit forecast was based on a number of assumptions outlined in the prospectus. The forecast was subject to independent review by Coopers & Lybrand (Securities) Ltd, who concluded in their report, "Nothing has come to our attention which causes us to believe that the directors' assumptions do not provide a reasonable basis for the Forecast."

(e) I am advised that the ASC is not aware of any such statements by Mr Willing. Any evidence that such a statement was made and information as to the context in which it was made should be provided to the ASC.
(f) I am advised that ASC inquiries have established that the NRMA Insurance Group had, between 31 March 1994 and 30 June 1994, sustained a decline in the value of its investments.

The prospectus discloses a reduction in the value of investments was expected. It discloses that the value of current fixed interest investments was expected to fall to $279.9m at 30 June 1994 from $477.4m at 31 March 1994 and current equities investments to $20.2m at 30 June 1994 from $21m at 31 March 1994. Non-current fixed interest investments were expected to fall to $1,724.2m at 30 June 1994 from $1,821.4m at 31 March 1994 and non-current equities investments to $1,603.2m at 30 June 1994 from $1,705m at 31 March 1994.

(g) I am advised that the ASC found no evidence during the course of post-vetting the NRMA prospectus to support the view that the directors of NRMA knew there was no prospect of achieving the prospectus forecast or that the expected value of the shares was falsely based.
(h) I am advised that the ASC has no evidence that the predictions were falsely based at the time of issue of the prospectus.

(i) I am advised that the directors did not inform the ASC to that effect, and the ASC is not aware as to whether they informed the Australian Stock Exchange or NRMA members to that effect. I am advised that no supplementary prospectus was issued during the life of the prospectus.

(j) I am advised that no balance sheet for the NRMA has been lodged with the ASC for the period ended 31 December 1994. Therefore the amount of any reduction in the value of NRMA by 31 December 1994, from the amount disclosed in the prospectus, is not available on the published information.
(k) I am advised that the ASC is not aware of any such admissions.
(l) I am advised that the ASC has not been made aware of any material which suggests that senior management were aware of the matters referred to during the periods in question.

I am advised that in relation to the payment of dividends, page 60 of the prospectus discloses the proposal to transfer $500 million of the share premium reserve created in the process of the restructure, to a retained earning account, with this amount to be available for distribution of dividends. The prospectus states that the transfer would have been subject to shareholder approval and that the directors of NRMA Holdings intended to make this recommendation to shareholders so that there would be no impediment to the future payment of dividends. Further, the prospectus states that the estimated dividend payable in the 1994/1995 year assumed that this capital reduction proceeded.
(m) I am advised that the answer is yes.

(n) I am advised that the NRMA profit and loss account for the year ended 30 June 1995 shows a consolidated operating loss before income tax benefit of $139.47 million. The Chief Executive Officer's report accompanying the 30 June 1995 accounts states "Unusually high levels of claims and awards made in the NSW Compulsory Third Party (Green Slips) insurance scheme and reduced returns on investments have affected our bottom line in a significant way."

(4)(a) I am advised that the 1995 annual reports state that the operating loss and extraordinary item after income tax for the consolidated NRMA Group for the year ended 30 June 1995 is $62.685 million and that the adjustment for the outside equity interests (mainly in respect of NRMA Insurance Group) is $63.141 million. I am also advised that the 1994 comparative figures referred to in the question appear in the 1995 annual reports.
(b) I am advised that the directors' report for the year ended 30 June 1995 refers at pages 39 and 40 to positive and negative factors affecting the result.
(5)(a) I am advised that Ms Ralph was a director and Vice-President of NRMA Limited during the development and promotion of the prospectus.
(b) I am advised that Ms Ralph was a member of a Board which recommended the demutualisation proposal to its members.
I am also advised that Ms Ralph has not attended nor voted at any meeting of the ASC where any matter relating to the future of the NRMA or its proposed float was discussed or decided.

(6) I am advised that the ASC did appear as amicus curae in those proceedings. The ASC made submissions on questions of law to assist the Court. The ASC did not appear in support of either party to the proceedings.

(7) I refer to Mr Alan Cameron's evidence to the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Corporations and Securities on 6 February 1995. The Full Federal Court determined that the use of the term "free shares" was misleading and deceptive in the specific context of other disclosures made in the NRMA prospectus, including the absence of a "No" case. It was in this context and in answer to a specific question from Senator Neal that the Chairman of the ASC referred to this as a matter of language.
However, I am advised that the ASC's attention has been drawn to the brief in question.
(b) No.
However, I am advised that the ASC's attention has been drawn to the advice in question.

(10) I am advised that the answer is yes. The ASC appeared amicus curae in the proceedings commenced by Ms Fraser and Mr Talbot against the NRMA and made submissions to assist the court on issues of interpretation of the law. Civil proceedings have now been brought by Mr Talbot against the NRMA and certain directors. The ASC is monitoring them but is not a party to those proceedings.

(11) I am advised that it is not the ASC's current intention to commence an investigation into these matters. The ASC will continue to closely observe developments. If evidence of any pecuniary loss or criminal conduct is provided to the ASC it will be assessed to determine appropriate action.
As the ASC is monitoring developments, I do not see any reason to direct that the ASC investigate these matters.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Assistant Treasurer, upon notice, on 23 October 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is it a fact that a Child Support Agency review officer recently discovered a potential case of fraud of the Department of Social Security.
(2) Are officers of the Child Support Agency and Child Support Review Office instructed to be aware of cases of potential fraud.
(3) Do guidelines exist for the investigation of cases of potential fraud by the Child Support Agency and Child Support Review Office.
(4) How many cases of fraud of the (a) Department of Social Security and (b) Australian Taxation Office has the Child Support Agency brought to the attention of these agencies.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Due to privacy constraints I am unable to provide details relating to specific cases of alleged fraud. However, there have been instances in which Child Support Review Officers have become aware of potential social security fraud cases and have accordingly reported these cases to the Department of Social Security for investigation.

(2) The secrecy provisions of the Child Support (Registration) Act 1988 and the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 prohibit the disclosure of protected information. However, sub-section 150(3) of the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 states:
Subsection (2) does not prevent the Registrar, a Deputy Registrar, or a person authorised by the Registrar or a Deputy Registrar, from communicating any protected information:
(a) to the Secretary to the Department of Social Security, or an officer or employee of that Department for the purpose of the administration of this Act; or

(b) to the Secretary to the Department of Social Security or the Department of Veterans' Affairs, or an officer or employee of either Department, for the purpose of the administration of any law of the Commonwealth relating to pensions, allowances or benefits; or

(c) to a person performing, as a person to whom this section applies, duties under or in relation to an Act of which the Registrar (whether as Registrar or Commissioner) has the general administration, or under regulations made under such Act, for the purpose of enabling the person to perform the duties; or

Officers of the Child Support Agency (CSA) and Child Support Review Office are provided with specific training in relation to the child support legislation and would be aware that certain information can be provided to the Department of Social Security (DSS). Training for these provisions is provided through the CSA technical training program. CSA staff and Child Support Review Officers are encouraged to identify fraud matters to be referred to the DSS.

(3) The Australian Taxation Office (ATO) has guidelines for the investigation of cases of potential fraud. CSA staff, as part of the ATO, are expected to adhere to these guidelines when dealing with potential fraud cases.
(4) No records on the number of cases of potential fraud referred to the DSS or the ATO have been retained by either the CSA or Child Support Review Office.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 25 October 1995:

PARA.TAB: Is it a fact that (a) there is a shortage of 1995 Perth Telstra White Pages and (b) a reprint will not be available before Christmas 1995; if so, (i) why did the shortage occur, (ii) how does Telstra determine the number of copies required and (iii) will he instruct Telstra to (A) resolve the problem quickly and (B) employ better planning for future issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: Yes. There is a shortage of 1995 Perth Telstra White Pages.
Telstra has advised that the remaining books will be printed and delivered before Christmas 1995. It has further advised that:
(i) the shortage was because of a paper shortage at the time of printing; and

(ii) that it determines the number of copies required based on last years orders, books remaining from the previous issue, economic growth and general community indicators, new telephone connections forecasts, municipal growth statistics and historical trends.

(iii) as I am advised by Telstra that the deliveries will be completed before Christmas this year, I see no need to intervene at this stage. Telstra has further advised that it previously ordered its paper supplies in advance, and that during the recent shortage suppliers fulfilled their contractual obligations as a priority over advance orders. To safeguard its future supply, Telstra now intends to have in place contractual arrangements with its suppliers by 1 January 1996.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 26 October 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is his Department providing funds for the national survey on small business attitudes to employment and education being conducted by Business in the Community Limited; if so what sum.
(2) Who commissioned the survey.
(3) When will the results of the survey be available.
(4) Has his Department provided funds for other projects managed by Business in the Community Limited; if so, (a) what sums have been paid and (b) for what purposes were they paid.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crean The Hon S.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) My Department is providing $26,950 for an Australia-wide survey of 5000 small and medium enterprises (SMEs) commissioned by Business in the Community Limited (BCL) to ascertain what SMEs believe are the qualities necessary to succeed in small business. This survey is one component of a project titled Maximising the employment opportunities in small business—the use of Key Competencies. TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 26 October 1995:

PARA.TAB: Will he move to legislate that pastoral leases extinguish native title; if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: No. The Government has consistently taken the view that the implication of the decisions of a majority of the judges in Mabo (No. 2) is that valid pastoral leases extinguished native title. However, it has also taken the approach that the most appropriate course is for the issue to be finally determined in the courts. In this way, indigenous parties and others can present material and fully argue the issue and the common law principles governing the recognition and extinguishment of native title can be applied.

It is not appropriate to pre-empt this judicial consideration by legislative action. Nor is it necessary to provide protection for pastoralists: any doubts about the validity of pre-1994 pastoral leases have been removed by the Native Title Act 1993 and that Act clearly allows for the extension, renewal and re-grant of pastoral leases after they expire, even if some residual native title rights have survived. Mining on pastoral leases can take place by following the `right to negotiate' regime.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 20 November 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Will the Government ensure that the (a) ALP and (b) union movement do not gain control of Australian superannuation funds.
(2) What level of control will he allow ACTU Super to take from institutional fund managers.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) There is no scope for the ALP, the union movement or any other interest group to gain control of superannuation funds in Australia.

Superannuation funds are run by trustees, who are subject to strict fiduciary obligations and prudential controls under the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) (SIS) Act 1993. The `checks and balances' in the SIS regime aim to ensure that superannuation funds are managed in the best interests of members as a whole, and not for sectional interests. These `checks and balances' include:
General requirements for equal numbers of employee and employer representatives on the trustee board of employer-sponsored funds with more than four members;

TAB.TAB: A decision of a trustee board will have effect only if it is carried by at least two-thirds of the total number of the trustees. This means, in effect, that it is impossible for the employee representatives on the trustee board (who may also be members of a union) to control the fund unless they consistently win the support of the employer representatives.

PARA.TAB: Approval processes for trustees for public offer funds by the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner.
Codification of the main fiduciary obligations of trustees, which are taken to be covenants in the fund's governing rules. These include duties to:

TAB.TAB: act honestly in all matters concerning the fund;
take the same care, skill and diligence as an ordinary prudent person would take in dealing with the property of another person for whom the person felt a moral obligation; and
ensure that the trustees' duties and powers are performed and exercised in the best interests of beneficiaries.

PARA.TAB: The trustee covenants set out in SIS clearly indicate that once a person assumes a trustee position, they are bound to act impartially and in the interest of all the members of the fund, irrespective of who has elected or appointed them to the position.

With regard to investment, the SIS Act requires trustees to formulate and give effect to an investment strategy which has regard to risk, return, the benefits of diversification, the need for liquidity and current and prospective liabilities. In addition, SIS requires that the trustees must ensure that the fund is maintained solely for the purpose of providing retirement income and ancillary benefits.

To safeguard the independence of trustees, SIS contains rules which protect trustees from victimisation, pressure or direction from other persons. Apart from limited exceptions, trustees must not be subject to directions from other persons and discretionary powers under the fund's governing rules cannot be exercised, and amendments made to those rules, without the consent of the trustees. In addition, trustees fulfilling their roles are also protected through criminal and civil actions against victimisation from any person.

SIS provides the superannuation industry supervisor—the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner—with extensive information gathering and fund investigation powers and with powers to suspend or remove trustees of superannuation funds in certain circumstances. In addition, the ISC conducts a national strategically targeted audit program to monitor compliance with the SIS regime and ensure that trustees are managing funds prudently.

The Government is conducting a major public education campaign to ensure trustees, particularly newly elected employee representative trustees, are aware of their duties and responsibilities to their members.

(2) There is no such body as ACTU Super with a privileged or favoured role in the management of superannuation. The SIS legislation which governs moneys once they become superannuation, accords no recognition or special treatment to the ACTU or trade union movement.

Under the SIS supervisory framework, trustees of superannuation funds have the ultimate responsibility for the viability and prudent operation of the funds, including fund investments. Trustees can appoint investment managers but they cannot delegate their basic investment responsibilities under SIS to formulate and give effect to an investment strategy. Where the trustees engage investment managers to implement the trustees' investment strategies for the fund, the trustees must ensure in writing, that the managers:
provide information on the investments and their returns; and
provide sufficient information for the trustees to make a judgement about the investment capabilities in managing the fund assets.
Trustees who intentionally or recklessly fail to comply with this standard may be subject to criminal liability under the SIS Act.

Where the superannuation funds invest in corporations through investment managers, trustees would retain the right to exercise voting rights in respect of the shares at any time. However, they would also be able to delegate voting rights to other parties such as fund managers.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 20 November 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Did any RAN personnel serving between 1960 and 1970 receive the Returned from Active Service (RAS) badge; if so, in which (a) ships and (b) operational areas did they serve.

(2) Did personnel from HMAS Vampire and HMAS Quickmatch qualify for the badge for deployment in Vietnam in 1962; if not, (a) why not and (b) what investigations have been conducted to ascertain their eligibility.
(3) Is it a fact that the awarding of the badge does not confer entitlement to veterans' benefits.
(4) Will he initiate a further review of the eligibility for the award of the badge as recognition of service in a dangerous operational area.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes. The Returned from Active Service Badge (RASB) was re-introduced in 1966 in respect of operational service in South East Asia retrospective to 31 July 1962, this being the date the Australian Army Training Team commenced operations in Vietnam. A member qualified for the RASB only if allotted for Special Service (ie special duty in a special area). Navy personnel qualified for the award of the RASB up to and including 11 January 1973, the end of Australia's involvement in Vietnam.
(a) HMA Ships involved are listed as follows:

HMAS Anzac; HMAS Boonaroo; HMAS Brisbane HMAS Curlew; HMAS Derwent; HMAS Duchess; HMAS Gull; HMAS Hawk; HMAS Hobart; HMAS Ibis; HMAS Jeparit; HMAS Melbourne; HMAS Parramatta; HMAS Perth; HMAS Queenborough; HMAS Quiberon; HMAS Snipe; HMAS Stuart; HMAS Swan; HMAS Sydney; HMAS Teal; HMAS Torrens; HMAS Vendetta; HMAS Vampire; HMAS Yarra
Other units—
RAN Band
817 Squadron (Helicopter flight embarked in HMAS Sydney)
725 Squadron (Helicopter flight embarked in HMAS Sydney)
Detachment of 723 Squadron (RAN Helicopter flight Vietnam)
Clearance Diving Team 3
(b) Operational areas in which HMA Ships operated were the North Borneo States, the Malay Peninsula and the Territory of Singapore and Vietnam (Southern Zone).
(a) The relevant commencement date for award of the RASB is 31 July 1962. HMAS Vampire and HMAS Quickmatch visited Saigon from 25—29 January 1962.

(b) Navy Office, in conjunction with Headquarters Australian Defence Force, carried out an examination of the service of HMAS Vampire and HMAS Quickmatch in Vietnam and determined that there was no entitlement to the RASB. This advice was contained in an Interdepartmental Committee report to Government. This report has been endorsed by both myself and my colleague, the Hon Frank Walker QC MP, Minister for Administrative Services.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction, upon notice, on 20 November 1995:

PARA.TAB: Is it a fact that, following changes to customs and excise legislation, breeders of horses not intended for use as stock horses are ineligible to claim diesel fuel rebate; if so, what (a) was the basis for the decision to remove their eligibility and (b) annual savings will result.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: It is not true that, following changes to the eligibility provisions of the Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme (the Scheme) contained in the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Act 1995, breeders of horses not intended for use as stock horses are ineligible to claim rebate. Such breeders have been ineligible for rebate since the Scheme's introduction in 1982. This is because the only provision which could be relevant to such breeders is the expression "the rearing of live-stock". The definition of livestock, which was not altered by the recent amendments, is:
"`live-stock' includes any animal reared for the production of food, fibres, skins, fur or feathers, or for its use in the farming of land".
This definition does not cover animals such as thoroughbred race horses, show horses and the like.
Therefore, as there has been no change there are no savings.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Holes in the Safety Net: The National Welfare Rights Network

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 21 November 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a discussion paper entitled "holes in the safety net", dated September 1995, which was prepared by the National Welfare Rights Network.

(2) Does the discussion paper refer to shortcomings in the Youth Protocol between the Commonwealth, States and Territories which have been identified by his Department; if so, what (a) are the shortcomings and (b) steps has he taken, and will he take, to remedy them.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes.

(2) (a) Yes. Some difficulties have arisen in relation to the timeliness of the process for the referral and assessment of young people who present to the Department of Social Security claiming to be homeless; acceptance by States and Territories of their responsibility for support during the assessment period; and, the provision of support and services in the longer term.

(b) In June this year I sought and obtained confirmation of the commitment of all State and Territory Community Services Ministers to assessing all under 15 year olds within the agreed timeframes. Ministers also confirmed their commitment to providing adequate support for homeless under 15 year olds from the time they are referred for assessment.

Where there are outstanding difficulties, these are taken up promptly at the local level between departments and also at regional and State coordination meetings. Instructions have been issued to Department of Social Security staff giving clear guidance as to their responsibilities towards young clients, continuing access by under 15 year olds to income support in exceptional circumstances and procedures to ensure that the best interests of young people remain the highest priority. I have provided a copy of these instructions to the honourable member.

An Evaluation is addressing the issues that have arisen, including those raised by community organisations, and a report will be considered by the Commonwealth and States/Territories Council of Community Services Ministers in April 1996.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 21 November 1995:

PARA.TAB: (a) Mr Neil Alan MacDonald was declared bankrupt under the Bankruptcy Act 1966 in November 1991, (b) Mr MacDonald's bankruptcy period was extended from 3 years by a further 5 years on 20 August 1992 in accordance with subsection 149D(1) of the Act and (c) Mr MacDonald applied for release from the bankruptcy period and was released on 20 August 1995; if so, is he further able to say on what basis Mr MacDonald was released from extended bankruptcy.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (a) Neil Alan MacDonald became bankrupt by an order of the court on 19 November 1991 and subsequently filed his Statement of Affairs on 19 February 1992.
(b) An objection was lodged by the trustee on 2 March 1993 pursuant to subsections 149D(1)(b) and 149D(1)(n) of the Act.
Paragraph 149D(1)(b) states:

after the date of bankruptcy the bankrupt continued to manage a corporation as mentioned in section 91A of the Corporations Law without having been given leave to do so under section 229 of that Law; and
Paragraph 149D(1)(n) states:
the bankrupt failed, whether intentionally or not, to disclose to the trustee the bankrupt's beneficial interest in any property.

Subparagraph 149A(2)(a)(i) allows the bankruptcy to be extended to a total of 8 years from the date the bankrupt files his Statement of Affairs for an objection lodged on the grounds of subparagraph 149D(1)(b) and 5 years for an objection lodged on the grounds of subparagraph 149D(1)(n).
(c) Mr MacDonald applied for review of the objection to discharge to the Inspector-General in Bankruptcy on 17 August 1995.
The objection was withdrawn on 20 September 1995 for the following reasons:
With respect to Subparagraph 149D(1)(b)—
The Australian Securities Commission completed their investigation into alleged breaches of sections 229 and 591 of the Corporations Law and no prosecution action was taken.
With respect to Subparagraph 149D(1)(n)—
The bankrupt disclosed the existence of the asset at his section 81 examination and the trustee subsequently realised the asset.
Once the objection was withdrawn, Mr MacDonald was discharged from bankruptcy.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 22 November 1995:

PARA.TAB: Is it a fact that persons (a) who can find only one hour's work per week and (b) undertaking unemployment training schemes are excluded from unemployment figures; if so, in each case, why.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (a) Among the criteria which the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) uses to classify someone as employed are that, during the survey reference week, they:
worked for one hour or more for pay, profit, commission or payment in kind in a job or business, or on a farm; or
worked for one hour or more without pay in a family business or on a farm.
This definition conforms with standards set by the International Labour Organisation. These standards are used by all major countries and international organisations, including the OECD.
The ABS data indicate that in October 1995, 2.9 per cent of employed persons worked 1-5 hours in the survey week, of whom 69.7 per cent preferred not to work more hours.

(b) Some labour market program participants can be expected to be selected by the ABS to take part in the ABS Labour Force Survey. The answers these program participants give to the Survey questions will determine how the ABS classifies them. I cannot say how program participants will respond to the survey questions, but the answers they give will be influenced by the type of program from which they are receiving assistance.

Participants in employment programs, such as JobStart, the National Training Wage, New Work Opportunities, the Landcare and Environment Action Program and the New Enterprise Incentive Scheme are likely to be classified as employed on the basis of their replies to the Labour Force Survey questions.
People who are not counted as employed would be classified as unemployed if they:
had actively looked for full-time or part-time work at any time in the four weeks up to the end of the reference week and

TAB.TAB: were available for work in the reference week, or would have been available except for temporary illness (ie lasting for less than four weeks to the end of the reference week); or
were waiting to start a new job within four weeks from the end of the reference week and would have started in the reference week if the job had been available then; or

PARA.TAB: were waiting to be called back to a full-time or part-time job from which they had been stood down without pay for less than four weeks up to the end of the reference week (including the whole of the reference week) for reasons other than bad weather or plant breakdown.

Participants in shorter-term labour market programs and those without a significant work component, such as courses under the JOBTRAIN program, may consider themselves to be still actively seeking work and available to start work. If so, they may meet the ABS criteria which would classify them as unemployed.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 22 November 1995:

PARA.TAB: Is his Department's branch office in Woodville, SA, to be closed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: Yes.

The Woodville Regional Office, is currently housed in a warehouse converted for use as office accommodation in 1979. It falls well short of current departmental standards with significant problems having been experienced with building services related to inadequate air-conditioning, sewerage leakage and rodent infestation. In addition, the office is spread over two levels, no provision is made for disabled access to the first floor and toilets are not available for public use on this floor.

This move is part of a broader strategy designed to enhance departmental services in the north west suburbs of Adelaide. This strategy includes relocation of the Croydon Regional Office to new premises located at Kilkenny (occupied on 26 June 1995), major upgrading of the Port Adelaide Regional Office and relocation of Torrensville Regional Office to newly constructed premises at Underdale.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 23 November 1995:

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 23 November 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has his attention been drawn to recent allegations concerning the treatment of foreign nationals on ships in Australian territorial waters.
(2) When will Australia ratify ILO Convention No. 147.

(3) Will Australia ratify ILO Convention (a) No. 55—Shipowners' Liability (Sick and Injured Seamen) 1936, (b) No. 130—Medical Care and Sickness Benefits 1969, (c) No. 56—Sickness Insurance (Sea) 1936, (d) No. 165—Social Security (Seafarers) (Revised) 1987, (e) No. 70—Social Security (Seafarers) 1946, and (f) No. 71—Seafarers' Pensions 1946; if not, in each case, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes, as Minister for Transport, I am aware of the recent allegations referred to by the honourable member. I also note that the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure is examining this matter as part of its on-going reference to look into ship safety.

(2) Consultations with the States and the Northern Territory on ILO Convention No. 147 [Merchant Shipping (Minimum Standards) Convention, 1976] are close to finalisation. Following their completion, further consideration will be given to ratification.

(3) Australia is not pursuing ratification of any of the six listed Conventions. Detailed information on Australia's position in relation to the Conventions is provided in the Department of Industrial Relations publication Status of ILO Conventions in Australia 1994 (SICA), which was tabled in both Houses of Parliament on 23 August 1995 and was debated in the House of Representatives Main Committee on 30 August 1995.
An indication of the position in respect of each Convention follows, updated where appropriate.

Convention 55: Since SICA was published, it has been established that the Commonwealth complies with Convention 55 by virtue of the Navigation Act 1912 and the Seafarers Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1992. However, as all other Australian jurisdictions have significant compliance problems, ratification is not possible. Nevertheless, the Commonwealth's ability to demonstrate compliance with Convention 55 is an important component in establishing Australia's compliance with Convention 147.
Conventions 130 and 165: These Conventions are not considered appropriate for implementation because Australia's social security system is not compatible with their requirements.
Conventions 56 and 70: These Conventions are closed to ratification, owing to the entry into force of a revising Convention, i.e., No. 165—Social Security (Seafarers) (Revised), 1987.
Convention 71: The Commonwealth does not appear to comply fully with this Convention because benefits under superannuation schemes applicable to seafarers are not in conformity with its requirements.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 23 November 1995:

PARA.TAB: If residents of the redistributed electoral division of Fisher (a) who can find only one hour's work per week and (b) undertaking unemployment training schemes are included in unemployment figures, how many unemployed persons were there in (i) redistributed Fisher; (ii) each local government area wholly or partly in redistributed Fisher; and (iii) each major town or region in redistributed Fisher in each month since January 1995.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (i), (ii) and (iii) The Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) Labour Force Survey provides the official basis for measuring unemployment. My Department does not have regional data from this survey on the number of persons working one hour a week. ABS data show that 253,600 part-time workers out of a total number of part-time workers of 2,057,100 worked between one and five hours in the reference period for the September 1995 survey in Australia as a whole. Of these 78,400 would have preferred to work more hours. The estimate of those working one hour only is not available.

The regular monthly Labour Force Survey does not provide information on the number of persons included in unemployment figures who are undertaking training schemes. The triennial ABS survey on training and education experience does provide information on labour force status and type of training undertaken at the broad regional level. The ABS can provide on request estimates for ABS labour force regions, but not for electorates. My Department does not have these figures.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 27 November 1995:

PARA.TAB: What guarantees did Australia receive at the recent APEC Summit which would ensure that other APEC countries will meet free trade obligations by the year 2000.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: There was no discussion of meeting free trade obligations by the year 2000. The Bogor commitment will achieve free and open trade and investment in the region by 2010 for industrialised economies and by 2020 for developing economies. Discussion at Osaka was directed to that end.

There is agreement on general principles that will guide APEC liberalisation, plus a process of consultation and review. One of the general principles is that of "comparability" ie all APEC members will endeavour to ensure the overall comparability of their trade and investment liberalisation. Individual members will now prepare detailed plans based on these general principles for submission to the next APEC leaders' meeting in Subic Bay. All APEC economies are contributing to the process. As evidence of their political commitment APEC leaders at Osaka announced a package of downpayment measures as a first step towards fulfilling their Bogor commitments.
I am confident that the approach developed will deliver quickly and effectively an open trading and investment regime in the Asia-Pacific by the Bogor target dates.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 27 November 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Did Australian Defence Industries recently sell its military clothing division to a Melbourne firm called Free `N' Easy; if so, for what price was it sold.

(2) Did the sale include a guarantee of an exclusive three year contract for the supply of military clothing to the Army and Air Force; if so, (a) what is the estimated value of the contract and (b) will the Army and Air Force pay higher prices for uniforms than if they were obtained on the open market.
(3) Is the arrangement consistent with the Government's competition policy.

(4) Is the Minister able to say whether Free `N' Easy was the successful tenderer for the provision of bulletproof vests to the NSW Police Force; if so, is he further able to say whether (a) Free `N' Easy submitted the lowest price and (b) the fabric on which the tender was based was inferior, used dated technology and exceeded the minimum weight specified in tender documentation.

(5) Is the Minister able to say whether Free `N' Easy was able to take unfair advantage of its privileged position in the supply of military uniforms to allow it to undercut the prices offered by other tenderers to the NSW Police Force.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Australian Defence Industries Limited completed the sale of its clothing business to Free `N' Easy Pty Ltd on 27 October 1995. The sale price is commercial-in-confidence to Australian Defence Industries.

(2) Yes, an arrangement which applies to combat clothing was agreed to facilitate a viable sale and as a quid pro quo for assurances from the buyer that the sale arrangements will include appropriate measures to support the interests of the employees affected by the change of ownership. (a) An annual value of $5m for each of the three years commencing 1 July 1996. (b) No, the agreement will ensure that prices remain competitive.

(3) The contract with Free `N' Easy Uniforms has not yet been finalised, but Defence will ensure that the terms and conditions fully satisfy its purchasing policy requirements in relation to price, quality and value for money.
(4) No, I am not privy to Free `N' Easy's business activities.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 27 November 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is it a fact that persons registered as seeking employment with the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) who are sent to training programs are no longer deemed to be unemployed.

(2) If an employer contacts the CES seeking an employee with the skills possessed by a person who has been sent to a training program, is the (a) employer notified that the person is available for interview or (b) person advised that an employer is seeking an employee with his or her skills; if not, in each case, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS), not the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES), has the responsibility for collecting the official unemployment statistics in Australia, which it does by means of a survey of households. According to the ABS, anyone who is not employed but is looking for work and available to start work is considered to be unemployed. Consequently, a person undertaking a training program who is looking for, and available to start, work would still be counted by the ABS as unemployed.

(2) (a) and (b) When an employer lodges a vacancy with the CES for an employee with specified skills, the CES is able to search its register of jobseekers to identify suitable candidates. Case managers can also examine their caseloads for suitable jobseekers. Jobseekers considered suitable by the CES or case manager (including those on training programs) may then be advised of the job vacancy and referred to the employer for interview. The employer is notified that the jobseeker is available for interview.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 28 November 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Which states have become parties to the 1965 International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination since the answer to question No. 1675 (Hansard, 18 August 1992, page 101) and on what dates did they do so.
(2) Have any states referred to in part (1) made declarations or reservations with respect to Article 4(a) of the convention; if so, what is the text of the reservation or declaration in each case.
(3) Which states have not yet become parties to the convention.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bilney The Hon G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The States which have become party to the Convention since August 1992 are as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia—18 January 1994—succession

PARA.TAB: (2) Monaco made the following reservation regarding article 4:

Monaco interprets the reference in that article to the principles of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, and to the rights enumerated in article 5 of the Convention as releasing States Parties from the obligation to promulgate repressive laws which are incompatible with freedom of opinion and expression and freedom of peaceful assembly and association, which are guaranteed by those instruments.

ANSWER.PARA: Switzerland made the following reservation concerning article 4:

PARA.TAB: Switzerland reserves the right to take the legislative measures necessary for the implementation of article 4, taking due account of freedom of opinion and freedom of association, provided for inter alia in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights.

ANSWER.PARA: United States of America made the following general declarations and reservations:

PARA.TAB: Upon signature:

"The Constitution of the United States contains provisions for the protection of individual rights, such as the right of free speech, and nothing in the Convention shall be deemed to require or to authorise legislation or other action by the United States of America incompatible with the provisions of the Constitution of the United States of America."
Upon ratification:
"I. The Senate's advice and consent is subject to the following reservations:

(1) That the Constitution and laws of the United States contain extensive protections of individual freedom of speech, expression and association. Accordingly, the United States does not accept any obligation under this Convention, in particular under articles 4 and 7, to restrict those rights, through the adoption of legislation or any other measures, to the extent that they are protected by the Constitution and laws of the United States.

(2) That the Constitution and laws of the United States establish extensive protections against discrimination, reaching significant areas of non-governmental activity. Individual privacy and freedom from governmental interference in private conduct, however, are also recognised as among the fundamental values which shape our free and democratic society. The United States understands that the identification of the rights protected under the Convention by reference in article 1 to fields of `public life' reflects a similar distinction between spheres of public conduct that are customarily the subject of governmental regulation, and spheres of private conduct that are not. To the extent, however, that the Convention calls for a broader regulation of private conduct, the United States does not accept any obligation under this Convention to enact legislation or take other measures under paragraph (1) of article 2, subparagraphs (1)(c) and (d) of article 2, article 3 and article 5 with respect to private conduct except as mandated by the Constitution and laws of the United States.

(3) That with reference to article 22 of the Convention, before any dispute to which the United States is a party may be submitted to the jurisdiction of the International Court of Justice under this article, the specific consent of the United States is required in each case.
II. The Senate's advice and consent is subject to the following understanding, which shall apply to the obligations of the United States under this Convention:

That the United States understands that this Convention shall be implemented by the Federal Government to the extent that it exercises jurisdiction over the matters covered therein, and otherwise by the state and local governments, to the extent that state and local governments exercise jurisdiction over such matters, the Federal Government shall, as necessary, take appropriate measures to ensure the fulfilment of this Convention.
III. The Senate's advice and consent is subject to the following declaration:
That the United States declares that the provisions of the Convention are not self-executing."
(3) The following states have not yet become parties to the Convention:

Andorra, Angola, Azerbaijan, Belize, Brunei Darussalam, Comoros, Democratic People's Republic of Korea, Djibouti, Dominica, Equatorial Guinea, Eritrea, Micronesia, Georgia, Guinea-Bissau, Honduras, Indonesia, Japan, Kazakstan, Kenya, Kiribati, Kyrgzstan, Liechtenstein, Lithuania, Malawi, Malaysia, Marshall Islands, Myanmar, Nauru, Oman, Palau, Paraguay, Saint Kitts and Nevis, Samoa, San Marino, Sao Tome and Principe, Saudi Arabia, Singapore, Thailand, Tuvalu, Vanuatu.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction, upon notice, on 29 November 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Who is responsible for defining the terms (a) "private access roads", (b) "at the place" in reference to where mining takes place and (c) "exploration" used in the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Act 1995.

(2) Is it a fact that confusion about conflicting interpretations of the terms between the Department of Industry, Science and Technology and the Australian Customs Service is causing concern within the mining industry; if so, when will definition of the terms be clarified.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The expressions "private access roads", "at the place where the mining operation is carried on" and "exploration" found in the definition of "mining operations", are not themselves defined in the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Act 1995. Therefore, these expressions are to be construed in the context of the legislation and are to take on their ordinary English meanings, unless a Court has decided, as a matter of law, that a particular expression should carry a technical meaning and not the ordinary meaning. There have been no Court decisions on the expressions to this time.

(2) The Australian Customs Service is responsible for the administration of the Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme and is therefore solely responsible for the giving of advice on the interpretation of terms or expressions contained in the legislation. The Department of Industry, Science and Technology does not give advice to beneficiaries of the Scheme on such matters and therefore, there have not been conflicting advices.
